narrators.name: Unknown

Topics: Chapter heading on zakat of camels

english_translation: Narrated by Ibrahim ibn al-Zibriqan al-Tamimi: Abu Khalid Amr ibn Khalid al-Wasiti narrated to us from Zayd ibn Ali, from his father, from his grandfather, from Ali who said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: There is no zakat in fewer than five heads of camels. When it reaches five, the zakat is one sheep. Then nothing until it reaches ten, when the zakat is two sheep. When it reaches fifteen, the zakat is three sheep. When it reaches twenty, the zakat is four sheep. When it reaches twenty-five, the zakat is five sheep. When it increases by one beyond that, the zakat is a young she-camel in her first year of breeding. If that is not available, then a young male camel one year older. This continues with increasing thresholds: at thirty-five, a young she-camel in her second year; at forty-five, a mature she-camel; at sixty, a pregnant she-camel; at seventy-five, a three-year-old she-camel; at ninety, two young she-camels in their second year; at one hundred and twenty, two mature she-camels. When camels become numerous, for every fifty a mature she-camel is due.

english_translation: Chapter: Zakat of Cattle

narrators.name: Unknown
narrators.full_name: Unknown Author/Compiler

Topics: Chapter heading on zakat of cattle

english_translation: Narrated by Ali: There is no zakat on cattle below thirty. When it reaches thirty, the zakat is a yearling or a young she-calf up to forty. When it reaches forty, the zakat is a mature cow up to sixty. When it reaches sixty, the zakat is two yearlings or young calves up to seventy. When it reaches seventy, the zakat is a mature cow and a yearling up to eighty. When it reaches eighty, the zakat is two mature cows up to ninety. When it reaches ninety, the zakat is three yearlings or young calves up to one hundred. When it reaches one hundred, the zakat is a mature cow and two yearlings. When cattle become numerous, for every thirty the zakat is a yearling or young calf, and for every forty a mature cow.

When it exceeds one hundred and twenty by one, the zakat is two sheep up to two hundred. When it exceeds two hundred by one, the zakat is three sheep up to three hundred. When sheep become numerous, for every hundred sheep the zakat is one sheep.

english_translation: Narrated by Ali: There is no zakat on silver below two hundred dirhams. When it reaches two hundred, the zakat is five dirhams. If it increases, it is calculated proportionally. There is no zakat on gold below twenty mithqals. When it reaches twenty mithqals, the zakat is half a mithqal. For any amount above that, it is calculated proportionally.

english_translation: Narrated by Ali: One who possesses fifty dirhams cannot take zakat, and one who possesses fifty dirhams cannot be given zakat. Also narrated: I asked Zayd ibn Ali about zakat on jewelry. He said: Pay zakat on gold and silver, but there is no zakat on pearls, rubies, or other precious stones. I asked Zayd ibn Ali about the wealth of an orphan - is there zakat on it? He said: No. I said: But the family of Abu Rafi narrate from Ali that he paid zakat on their wealth. He said: We of the Prophet's family reject this. I asked Zayd ibn Ali about what comes from the sea such as amber and pearls. He said: There is nothing on that. I asked Zayd ibn Ali about mines of gold, silver, lead, iron, quicksilver, and copper. He said: There is a fifth on those. I asked him about mines of precious stones like agate. He said: There is nothing on those. I asked him about a mukatab slave - is there zakat on him? He said: No. I asked him: Can zakat be given to one of your relatives? He said: It cannot be given to one upon whom the Imam has imposed maintenance, and all heirs are those upon whom the Imam has imposed maintenance. Zayd ibn Ali said: Do not give from your zakat to the Qadariyyah, the Murji'ah, the Kharijites, nor to those who wage war against the Prophet's family, peace be upon them. I asked Zayd ibn Ali about accelerating zakat before its time is due. He said: It is permissible. I asked him about a man who has one hundred fifty dirhams and five dinars. He said: Zakat is due on that. But if either category is below the minimum, no zakat is due on any of them. Zayd ibn Ali said: It is not permissible to give zakat to the people of the covenant, nor is it lawful to give them zakat from obligatory charity. Zayd ibn Ali said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ obligated charity on ten things: gold and silver, wheat and barley, dates and raisins, corn, camels, cattle, and sheep. Zayd ibn Ali said: Zakat cannot be used for the shroud of a dead person, for building a mosque, nor to free a slave. Zayd ibn Ali said: Zakat is distributed among the eight categories mentioned by Allah in His Book, and if you give it to only one category, it suffices you.

english_translation: Chapter: Land of Ushr (Tithe)

narrators.name: Unknown
narrators.full_name: Unknown Author/Compiler

english_translation: Narrated by Ali: There is no zakat on what the land of ushr (tithe) produces from dates, raisins, wheat, barley, or corn until it reaches five wasq (measures). One wasq equals sixty sa' (pecks). When it reaches that amount, zakat becomes due. What is watered by rainfall, opened channels, or natural flow is subject to the ushr (one-tenth). What is watered by wheel or bucket is subject to half the ushr (one-twentieth).

english_translation: Chapter: Zakat of al-Fitr (Charity at the End of Ramadan)

narrators.name: Unknown
narrators.full_name: Unknown Author/Compiler

Topics: Chapter heading on zakat of Fitr

english_translation: Narrated by Ali: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: Zakat of Fitr is obligatory on every Muslim, whether one is free or enslaved, male or female, young or old. One must give it for oneself and for all those in one's household: half a sa' of wheat, or one sa' of dates, or one sa' of barley. Also narrated: I asked Zayd about a man who has less than fifty dirhams. He said: Zakat of Fitr is not obligatory on him. One who has fifty dirhams cannot take Zakat of Fitr, and Zakat of Fitr is obligatory on one who has fifty dirhams. I asked Zayd about the measure of sa' - what is its quantity? He said: Five and one-third ratlal using the Kufa ratlal (measure of weight).
